A ring \(R\) is called Noetherian if every ascending chain of ideals \(\mathfrak{a}_{1} \subset \mathfrak{a}_{2} \subset \ldots \subset R\) becomes stationary after finitely many steps, or equivalently, every ideal of \(R\) is finitely generated.

For ideals $\mathfrak{a}, \mathfrak{b}$ in a ring $R$, the product $\mathfrak{a} \cdot \mathfrak{b}$ is defined as $\left\{\sum_{i=1}^{<\infty} a_{i} b_{i} ; a_{i} \in \mathfrak{a}, b_{i} \in \mathfrak{b}\right\}$.
Does the concept of a/an Noetherian ring need to be defined for a definition of a/an Product of Ideals to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
The definition of the product of ideals in a ring R involves taking sums of products of elements from two ideals, \(\mathfrak{a}\) and \(\mathfrak{b}\), within the ring. This definition is purely algebraic and does not inherently require any specific properties of the ring R beyond the basic ring structure and the concept of ideals.

On the other hand, a Noetherian ring is defined by a property concerning the behavior of chains of ideals within the ring, specifically that every ascending chain of ideals eventually stabilizes, or that every ideal is finitely generated. This property is about the structure and behavior of ideals in a broader sense within the ring.

The definition of the product of ideals does not depend on whether the ring is Noetherian or not. The concept of a Noetherian ring introduces additional conditions on the behavior of ideals, but it is not necessary for the basic algebraic operation of forming the product of two ideals. The product of ideals can be defined and understood in any ring, regardless of whether it is Noetherian.
